186008285.review:
just no. dont get this. its over glorified by other reviews who only care about nostalgia.for a newcomer it doesnt even feel easy to pickup. it sure is a waste of time thats for sure.

i dont have nostalgia for this and honestly it just came off as kinda overrated and boring.
wow this really is a racing game yet you cant unlock new cups unless you get a perfect score on any of the ones provided. online barely connects to another person's lobby so you may as well just play for the single player grandprix.

oh and enjoy going round a ring for 10 minutes with just one car, you have to individually unlock other cars to play the other modes. forced to playing dirt races for 30 mins. legit bored the ever living sh!t out of me.

also holy hell the controls are god awful on controller, sticks dont feel responsive enough that it feels like im sliding on ice. doesn't even feel fun after coming 4th on long f*cking laps and having to restart the grandprix from the beginning attempting to grind your way through bs rng luck and hope you dont screw up during the race.

only thing i liked was the soundtrack, other than that im just disappointed in this crap i saw so much positive reviews for.

185731370.review:
FlatOut 2 is a perfect blend of speed, chaos, and fun, making it a true classic in the racing genre. The destructible environments, incredible physics engine, and the sheer satisfaction of smashing into opponents set it apart.

While the visuals might feel dated by today’s standards, the energetic and dynamic gameplay more than makes up for it. If you’re a fan of arcade racing games, FlatOut 2 is an absolute must-play.

185719268.review:
1. Казульная - никакие препятствия, аварии, столкновения, перевороты по-сути особо и не влияют на отставание в гонке, потому что респавн происходит быстро, и сразу даёт неплохую начальную скорость. В игре про грязные гонки, когда выводишь соперника с трассы, это особо ни на что не влияет, особенно, когда знаешь, что соперники наглые читеры.
2. Душная - боты сначала проигрывают отставая на круг, но в какой-то момент начинают откровенно читерить, 2 случая из моей игровой практики: бот едет быстрее игрока, заносясь то вправо, то влево, у него не получается даже ехать прямо, но обгонять это ему не мешает; боты врезаются раза три подряд, отстают на добрую минуту, но уже через считанные секунды на хвосте. Но есть и плюсы, иногда эти хитрые дурики так разгоняются, чтоб держать игрока в тонусе, что не могут контролировать скорость, и разбиваются вплоть до вылета с гонки.
3. Однообразная - разбили игру на несколько этапов, в каждом по несколько кубков, в каждом по несколько гонок. От "гонок", "ралли" и "стрит-рэйсинга" ждёшь разных типов трасс, а в итоге 100+ раз проходишь 10-15 одних и тех же, по-сути, одинаковых колец, меняются только авто, которые просто не такие ободранные, как в предыдущем этапе.

Из действительно отличных аспектов только станты и саунд. Благодаря им игра и стала легендарной, мне кажется. В остальном видно, что сначала сделали гиперказуальную игру, а когда поняли, накрутили ботам лишних примочек, и вот уже и сложно стало, только неоправданно.

185679774.review:
FlatOut 2 is an excellent PS2-era arcade racer that still holds up even under the shadow of Bugbear's newest Wreckfest series. There's a lot to say about this game, and a lot of the talking points don't really flow too nicely in a paragraph-to-paragraph sort of way, so here's some categorized information:

[h3]Core Game-Loop[/h3]
The progression of FlatOut is linear, for my taste. You start with a small amount of money to purchase a cheap banger car, you participate in events, and you use your winnings to buy more expensive, better cars to use instead.
Your cars sit in three categories: "Derby Class," "Race Class," and "Street Class," each only allowed to drive in their respective class, so you don't see a $100,000 sports car smoking a lineup of derby beaters.
Within each class, your selection of cars ranges mostly from sporty to muscley to plain old pickup trucks. But the car at the right of the list is always better than the cars to its left. The Road King is the poster child for FlatOut, for example, but even it sits just to the left of the Bullet GT—a more powerful, significantly less expensive car unlocked shortly later.
The progression's a little bland as someone who's seen it before, but it's more than made up for in the racing gameplay.

There's a gamey "nitro" system that builds up charge as you hit physics objects for the first time on a track, crash into other drivers, and take jumps. I've found it mostly better to maintain a clean racing line and keep traction so you can constantly accelerate. But the nitro is invaluable if you crash and want to regain speed before the people behind you can catch up, or if you're behind somebody you hate.
(You also get a bonus for wrecking other contestants during a race, so consider playing nice [i]discouraged.[/i] Play mean. Kill Jack Benton.)

[h3]The AI:[/h3]
"Who the hell is Jack Benton?" you ask. Well,
The AI racers are another standout feature of FlatOut 2. There aren't many other racers, but they each have their own driving style and car preference, which offers an illusion of identity and feels much more engaging than if the races were against nameless CPU opponents with a randomly selected vehicle.
With their cars and personalities, you're more or less only competing with Sofia Martinez, Jack Benton, and Jason Walker, with some dopes behind you to make the competition look bigger.
Jack and Jason are more aggressive, more likely to slam into you for no reason and piss you off. Jason's more likely to pull mean tricks like this but usually crashes into walls when he tries to get you. Sofia, however, is [i]fast[/i], and [i]wants to win[/i], and when you've got the slower car, the best you can do is slam her around and get as much of a lead as you can before she recovers.
Katie's a tough racer in derby class but turns into a punching bag afterward. She's a real thrill to send into a tree on your way to the finish line. Ray or Sally can push their way into the front of the pack but usually can't hold onto their placement for long.
And if there's one car left ramming around at the end of a demolition derby, it's usually some jeep or truck belonging to Frank Malcov. Frank sucks in races, but he's got a lot of aggression to let out, I guess.
That makes seven AI racers—just seven. But I think their distinction makes up for their lack of quantity.

[h3]The Physics Engine:[/h3]
Since we've just touched on derbies with Frank,
The vehicle destruction was [i]crazy[/i] ahead of its time, and even coming to it in late 2024, I found myself impressed by the tech on display. Even now, you don't see vehicle destruction in racing games due to the prominence of licensed vehicles and car manufacturers' consistent stand against any damage befalling a [i]digital model[/i] of their products within a work of fiction.
Compare the indestructible cars in Forza to the destructible ones in FlatOut, Burnout 3, or the like, and you'll see that the differences are [i]stark[/i]. Yeah, it's neat driving a Dodge Challenger SRT through a Grand Prix, but it'd be more neat if my car looked the part after smacking its entire left side into a wall at 100MPH.

The physics objects in the tracks also stood out for a PS2 game, and though they did introduce a level of unpredictability and turn some of my wins into losses, I suppose that was the point, and at least it also screwed the AI racers over sometimes.

The driving itself felt sticky and difficult to get nice drifts with. The derby cars are slower and, I assume, better at gripping the loose ground, which made ample sense to me. But the "street-class cars" tended to cling to dirt and pavement like Velcro, even as they flew around small corners at nearly 80MPH. You get used to it after a little while, and the game feels plenty comfortable to play afterward, but it's still worth noting that all tires in this game are very grippy.

[h3]The Race-Tracks:[/h3]
Boy, I love a game with a juicy physics engine, don't you? But just like any action game needs a good environment to fight through, a racing game needs good tracks—and FlatOut 2's tracks are all [i]great[/i] to race on. Most of them have some alternate route or another—some forks in the road have an objectively faster and slower route to drive, but sometimes the outside routes are better for maintaining speed if you're already going too fast, too quick.
There are usually some rocks off the side of the track to punish cutting corners too short, and plenty of jumps that can vary from "the smartest path to take," to "a dastardly trap to put your hubris in check."
Considering the work put into other things I've mentioned, I can forgive the somewhat low track variety.

[h3]The Sound Design:[/h3]
The sound's at the bottom of the list because it's probably the weakest part of the game. The soundtrack is good but relatively small and repetitive, with no option to skip a song or black-list it playing. I can listen to Rob Zombie and Audioslave all day, and your mileage with the soundtrack may vary, but some other artists got to grate me after a point, and I found myself muting the music to play my own in the background.
The sound design underneath the music also bothered me a lot for some reason that I can't quite put into words, no matter how hard I tried for this paragraph. The crashes were crunchy and satisfying, and the engines were loud and pretty. But there was something in the sound of the ground under the tires, or maybe the plants whooshing by on the side of the road—something along those lines—that felt uncanny and underdeveloped to me. It's no big problem, to be sure—you're almost definitely going to blast music over the game's sound effects—but it wasn't any good in the moments I'd forgotten to unpause my music alongside my game.

[h3]In Summary:[/h3]
The game's a little flawed, but it's still outstanding and worth picking up even if you've already played Wreckfest.
A $10 base asking price is a bargain, and it's stealing if you can grab this thing on a 50% off sale.
Solid 9 out of 10—a potential 10/10 classic, but -1 for some minor frustrations.

185356420.review: I was born in the early 90's and would have thought this was an absolute all-timer if I discovered it in 2006. However, I discovered it in 2025. Being a game from 2006, it is starting to show it's age a bit (although not as much as many from the era.) Visuals are okay, and game play is good. What really sells me on this game is the sound track. This has to be one of the best ROCK/POP PUNK soundtracks to any game I have played. Even though I did not play this game in 2006, the music makes me feel like i'm back to playing PS2 in my parents basement. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes racing with some light vehicle combat - especially if you are nostalgic for the PS2/Xbox Era. It's regularly on sale for $1.99 and I would absolutely recommend picking it up at that price.

185342867.review:
Адреналиновые гонки и безумный хаос

Одна из тех игр, которая остаётся классикой для фанатов аркадных гонок. Если вы любите скорость, разрушения и возможность выбить соперника с трассы, то эта игра именно то, что нужно.

Здесь нет места для размеренных заездов: каждая гонка — это битва, где вам предстоит не только гнаться за финишем, но и выживать в условиях тотального хаоса. Барьеры разлетаются, машины сталкиваются, а каждое столкновение сопровождается эффектными визуальными разрушениями.
Геймплей сочетает в себе классические гонки и уникальные элементы, которые сделали FlatOut 2 легендарной. Система повреждений великолепна: каждый удар, каждый скрежет ощущается, а машины разлетаются на куски, добавляя реализма и драйва.
Графика на момент выхода игры была впечатляющей, и даже сегодня она смотрится достойно благодаря ярким трассам и детализированным разрушениям.

FlatOut 2 особенно хорош в мультиплеере. Локальные и сетевые гонки становятся настоящим испытанием для ваших дружеских отношений: подрезать друга перед финишем или выбить его с трассы — это незабываемое удовольствие.

185214353.review:
Классика жанра. Финские разработчики из [b]Bugbear Entertainment[/b] не только не испортили серию, но и сделали сиквел, превосходящий оригинальную игру во всех аспектах.

Графика стала ярче, цвета сочнее, физика реалистичнее, а картинка плавнее. Оригинальные мини-игры с вылетающим водителем стали разнообразнее, прохождение обязательно для закрытия кубков на 100%. Водители-соперники теперь не просто обезличенные машинки в таблице рейтинга, а персонажи со своими историями, характером и поведением на трассе. 16 часов прохождения на 100% пролетели незаметно!

184562785.review:
A sad reminder that this genre used to be so much more than it is now.

FlatOut 2 might be the best $2 I've ever spent on a game. It really is that good. The physics still hold up and are more impressive than most racers on the market today. When it comes to single-player, this might have the best moment-to-moment gameplay I've experienced in a racing game. I believe the secret sauce, in addition to the truly visceral car gore, is the copious amounts of debris you'll find on the tracks.

Unlike most racers, FlatOut's tracks are not clean. Even most dirt racing games have tracks that I would consider to be "clean". All you need to do is adjust to the physics and handling in most of those cases. But in FlatOut, a piece of trash on the road can be the difference between a podium finish or total failure. This introduces a huge element of risk and reward. Shortcuts and jumps can reward you with tons of boost, but they can be very punishing. Sometimes it's wiser to take the safer route.

You can never truly feel confident in the racing line you take. If you aren't paying attention to what's directly ahead of you, you will spin out, barrel roll, etc. While the game incentivizes rough play with your opponents, you still absolutely have to be on your guard. It's incredibly easy to lose control while wrestingling with the other drivers, but that's the thrill of it. 

Races rarely become time trials while you're ahead. Finishing in first place almost never feels like a guarantee. The game makes you naturally form rivalries with the AI opponents by giving them names, faces, and distinct vehicles. Sometimes my goal wasn't even to finish first place in a given race, but to outperform my rival so I could win the cup. 

This is truly a fantastic racing game and it's an absolute steal if you can get it on sale. It runs perfectly out of the box despite its age.

184150045.review:
At the end of 2024, there's very much no reason to review and explain this time-proven classic, which everyone knows and most of us had played already. Instead, I only want to focus on the 2024 update (re-release, call it however you want) which added some new features, but also introduced some problems into the game. During sales, this game is rather cheap, so there's hardly a reason to think twice about buying it, just go for it if you don't have it yet. In case you'd find the issues below as too big of a problem, there's an option to revert to the original release, which would remove the good changes though and [i]possibly[/i] (haven't tested it) cause issues with your saves, at least as far as Steam Cloud goes. Still, I want to provide information and my personal opinion about the changes, so let's get into it.

[h1]THE GOOD STUFF[/h1]
+ Multiplayer restored via OpenSpy
+ Steam Workshop
+ Steam Cloud

[h1]THE BAD STUFF[/h1]
- Game HUD and whole interface is streched out in widescreen resolutions
- Czech localization lacks any diacritics (could be the case for other languages too), therefore I'd rather play in English (the extra languages weren't offered in Steam before, but if they don't work properly, what's the point)
- Game intro is the original low-res 4:3 video cropped to 16:9 (and when you have a 4:3 resolution enabled, it shrinks the 16:9 crop into a 4:3 frame)

[h1]THE QUESTIONABLE STUFF[/h1]
? While the HUD is streched at all times, the actual game during races, derby and stunts isn't and you therefore have some sort of widescreen support. However, they made the FOV way too wide, especially when pressing nitro. I guess the FOV is tied to how wide your monitor is. It takes time getting used to it, could be pretty uncomfortable if you played the game before this.
? Blood Brothers by Papa Roach now plays during races too. No idea why. The changelog says they "restored" this song, but it was never playing in races, it's an exclusive stunt mode song along with Mötley Crüe's Dr. Feelgood (which by the way remains a stunt-only song here). So unless the previous Steam release didn't have this song at all, there was no restoration done and if there was, they didn't respect the original setup. After almost two decades, it's weird to hear it without the arena sound filter.

[h1]THE VERDICT[/h1]
All Bugbear-produced Flatouts got updates this year, but the original Flatout and Ultimate Carnage have less issues to them. Out of these three games, Flatout 2 has the worst implementation as far as compatibility goes. They did a much better job with widescreen support for the original Flatout, where the HUD stays in correct aspect ratio and zero changes were done to the FOV. At the same time though, Flatout 2 is also the only game where you can play online out of these three, at least when it comes to using the official Steam version.
